item.title: "In this particular case, the family would not have been...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

"In this particular case, the family would not have been asked to post a $25,000 bond to bring home their eleven-year-old child," notes Elise Logemann, the ACLU of Colorado's juvenile-justice policy counsel. "Had this family not had the ability to post the bond, which many families do not, the child — who has autism — might have remained behind bars in a secure juvenile facility."

https://www.westword.com/…/shocking-video-of-autistic-child…

The child banged his head in a patrol car for hours.

westword.com

Disturbing Video of Autistic Child Handcuffing: Lawsuit and More

The child banged his head in a patrol car for hours.The child banged his head in a patrol car for hours.
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: “I felt like they were trying to put him in the system,”...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

“I felt like they were trying to put him in the system,” Shandie said about J.J., her 16-year-old son who has autism. “Why not call me first? I could’ve helped de-escalate the situation.” After many times being kicked off of school grounds at random, J.J. was ticketed for harassment after making a teacher feel "uncomfortable." Shandie was never made aware of the situation by the school. Instead, she would later receive a call from a police officer. Read more about Shandie and J.J.'s story: https://aclu-co.org/shandie-harris-and-her-son-j-j/
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: Michelle Hanson always wanted her kids to go to their...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Michelle Hanson always wanted her kids to go to their neighborhood schools. That was until the day her 11-year-old son A.V., who has autism, ended up handcuffed in the back of a police car for hours, sobbing, injured, and traumatized when school resource officers decided to intervene in a situation they didn't understand and were not equipped to handle. Read more about Michelle and A.V.'s story: https://aclu-co.org/michelle-hanson-and-her-son-a-v/
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: TAKE ACTION: Tell your legislator that it's time to end the...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

TAKE ACTION: Tell your legislator that it's time to end the school-to-prison pipeline in Colorado. SB21-071 is a bill intended to limit the use of juvenile detention and eliminate money bail for children. Colorado's children need school counselors, not cops. https://action.aclu.org/send-message/co-sro-action
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: BREAKING: An 11-year-old student with autism was handcuffed,...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

BREAKING: An 11-year-old student with autism was handcuffed, restrained in the back of a police car for hours and held on a $25,000 bond after an unnecessary School Resource Officer response. Today we are suing the Douglas County school district and officers involved in this case, for violating the child's rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Fourth Amendment.

https://aclu-co.org/aclu-files-lawsuit-against-douglas-coun…
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: Reforming inequitable pretrial systems is necessary to create a...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Reforming inequitable pretrial systems is necessary to create a system where people who are accused of commiting low-level crimes aren’t behind bars simply because they can't afford to pay bail. https://www.denverpost.com/…/colorado-arrest-bail-reform-c…/

The bill, which passed its first legislative hurdle Thursday, would prohibit Colorado law enforcement from taking people into custody on a range of crimes, including misdemeanors and some low-level…

denverpost.com

Which crime suspects should be booked into jail? Which should pay bail? Colorado lawmakers could decide this year.

The bill, which passed its first legislative hurdle Thursday, would prohibit Colorado law enforcement from taking people into custody on a range of crimes, including misdemeanors and some low-level…The bill, which passed its first legislative hurdle Thursday, would prohibit Colorado law enforcement from taking people into custody on a range of crimes, including misdemeanors and some low-level…
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: Schools with mental health services see improved attendance...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Schools with mental health services see improved attendance rates, better academic achievement, and higher graduation rates.

But nationwide, 90 percent of students are in public schools that fail to meet the minimum recommended student-to-counselor ratio.

Instead, funding for police in schools has been on the rise. It’s time we reverse these trends. Students need counselors, not cops.
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: John Peckham has served six years in prison and fears his prison...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

John Peckham has served six years in prison and fears his prison sentence will become a death sentence. He hopes the Governor will reconsider making vaccines and safe release a priority. "You cannot self-distance, and that is why it spread so quickly in here," Mr. Peckham said.

item.title: Fred Harris lost 20 years of his life because of the failed war...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Fred Harris lost 20 years of his life because of the failed war on drugs and sentencing failures in the criminal legal system. A massive systemic problem requires a transformational solution. Clemency can save lives and offer long overdue second chances. Redemption is real. https://www.9news.com/…/73-937fc010-4609-47b2-b2fe-f91fc69d…

If Fred Harris was convicted of the same crimes today, he'd likely only face about eight years in prison.

9news.com

After being sentenced to 96 years in prison for small drug charges he served 20, granted clemency and is free

If Fred Harris was convicted of the same crimes today, he'd likely only face about eight years in prison.If Fred Harris was convicted of the same crimes today, he'd likely only face about eight years in prison.
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: The Aurora independent investigation report confirms in stark...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

The Aurora independent investigation report confirms in stark terms what the community has long understood: Aurora police killed Elijah McClain. Mr. McClain was the innocent victim of multiple violations of longstanding law that is supposed to limit the authority of law enforcement. The family of Elijah McClain deserves justice. The community is calling for accountability. Aurora decision-makers cannot and must not ignore these calls. http://acluco.org/3qO8NX5

February 23, 2021 DENVER – The following statement can be attributed to Mark Silverstein, Legal Director for ACLU of Colorado. “The Aurora independent investigation report confirms in stark terms what the community has long understood: Aurora police killed Elijah McClain. Mr. McClain … Continu...

item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: Using an arbitrary system to decide which views and beliefs can...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Using an arbitrary system to decide which views and beliefs can and can’t be expressed clearly violates the First Amendment. We must hold HOAs and Metro Districts to the Constitution, and ensure that residents can exercise their right to free speech.

https://www.denverpost.com/…/aclu-lawsuit-free-speech-hoa-…/

The American Civil Liberties Union of Colorado filed a federal lawsuit Tuesday challenging neighborhood subdivision rules that prohibit residents from displaying certain flags and signs on their pr…

denverpost.com

ACLU sues Denver-area subdivision for barring pride flags, social justice signs

The American Civil Liberties Union of Colorado filed a federal lawsuit Tuesday challenging neighborhood subdivision rules that prohibit residents from displaying certain flags and signs on their pr…The American Civil Liberties Union of Colorado filed a federal lawsuit Tuesday challenging neighborhood subdivision rules that prohibit residents from displaying certain flags and signs on their pr…
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: HOAs and Metro Districts shouldn’t have the authority to...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

HOAs and Metro Districts shouldn’t have the authority to arbitrarily approve or deny individuals the right to express views and beliefs without consultation of a fixed set of guidelines that apply to everyone. HOAs and Metro Districts must be held to constitutional standards, just like larger units of government — and the Colorado legislature must be responsible for ensuring that they don’t have the power or ability to violate individuals’ First Amendment rights. Read the full press release: https://aclu-co.org/aclu-challenges-subdivision-rules-proh…/
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: Born in 1862, Ida B. Wells was an investigative journalist,...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Born in 1862, Ida B. Wells was an investigative journalist, teacher, civil rights activist, and one of the founders of the NAACP. The ACLU of Colorado celebrates the legacy of Ms. Wells, and continues to work toward preserving and extending constitutionally guaranteed rights to people who have historically been denied them on the basis of race. #BlackHistoryMonth
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: When HOAs attempt to regulate a neighborhood’s signs or flags,...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

When HOAs attempt to regulate a neighborhood’s signs or flags, they strip residents of their constitutionally protected right to free speech. Coloradans should be allowed to express their views and beliefs, no matter their political nature, uninhibited by and without retribution from their HOA.

https://www.westword.com/…/new-colorado-hoa-fight-over-blac…

The homeowners association fears contention among neighbors.

westword.com

Lafayette HOA Fight Over Black Lives Matter Sign Could Spur New Law

The homeowners association fears contention among neighbors.The homeowners association fears contention among neighbors.
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: In 2019, 65% of immigrants who navigated deportation cases in...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

In 2019, 65% of immigrants who navigated deportation cases in Aurora did so without legal representation. Reports show that a statewide immigrant legal defense fund would not only benefit our immigrant community but also local and state economies.

https://www.westword.com/…/immigrant-legal-defense-fund-wou…

A statewide fund would cost $15.2 million annually, but pay off with $18.6 million in savings and revenues.

westword.com

Report Shows Positive Financial Impact of Immigrant Legal Defense Fund

A statewide fund would cost $15.2 million annually, but pay off with $18.6 million in savings and revenues.A statewide fund would cost $15.2 million annually, but pay off with $18.6 million in savings and revenues.

item.title: Pauli Murray's work as a civil rights lawyer shaped the...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Pauli Murray's work as a civil rights lawyer shaped the foundations of early social justice movements. Her senior thesis, arguing against the "separate but equal" doctrine, would later be used in Brown v. Board to dismantle racial segregation in schools. #BlackHistoryMonth
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: Colorado prisons have experienced some of the harshest impacts...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Colorado prisons have experienced some of the harshest impacts of COVID-19 statewide. Governor Polis must make public health and equity priorities, and ensure that our communities are safe through a comprehensive vaccine distribution plan for prisons.

coloradosun.com/2021/02/12/covid-prisons-vaccination-opinion

Gov. Jared Polis isn’t listening. So far he’s refusing to implement widespread vaccine distribution in prisons in phases 1b or 2 of Colorado’s distribution schedule — despite prisons being one of the settings hardest hit by COVID-19 in the state. There’s a consensus among many experts that...

coloradosun.com

Opinion: Polis must enact a COVID-19 vaccination plan for Colorado’s hard-hit prisons

Gov. Jared Polis isn’t listening. So far he’s refusing to implement widespread vaccine distribution in prisons in phases 1b or 2 of Colorado’s distribution schedule — despite prisons being one of the settings hardest hit by COVID-19 in the state.
